newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 29.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 29.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- President Fidel Ramos rejects China's demand for the immediate release of 21 Chinese fishermen arrested near a disputed Scarborough Shoal in South China Sea. (PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER)

- Foreign affairs secretary Domingo Siazon rejects a proposal by Senate Majority Floor leader Francisco Tatad to renegotiate the RP-US Mutual Defenese Treaty, saying the pact is in good order. (MANILA CHRONICLE)

- More than half of Filipinos continue to express satisfaction over the way President Fidel Ramos performs his duties, according to the latest survey by the Asia Reasearch Organisation. (PHILIPPINE STAR)

- A slowdown in the manufacturing sector is expected to dampen the country's economic growth in the first quarter although the government remians optimistic of meeting its economic targets for the year. (BUSINESSWORLD)
- The Philippines may have to extend for a few more months its economic programme with the International Monetary Fund because of the delay in the passage of the tax reform law. (MANILA TIMES)
- The Central Bank lowers its overnight borrowing and lending rates by two percentage points. (PHILIPPINE STAR)
